p: Laurent Cauffriez has a doctorate from the University of Valenciennes (France), and is an Associate Professor at the ENSIAME in Valenciennes (The National School of Engineering for Computer Science, Automation, Mechanics and Electronics). He is a member of the LAMIH research laboratory (Laboratory of Industrial and Human Automation, Mechanics, and Computer Science), which is associated with the CNRS (National Center for Scientific Research). He primarily teaches courses on operating safety, the simulation of automated production systems, and production management. His research centers on dependability in complex systems and is applied principally to production systems, distributed control/command systems and, more recently, railway systems. He is the editor of one book, “Fieldbus: description and choice criteria” (Paris, Hermès/Ciame, 1999, ISBN 286601-7242, in French), and the author of two chapters in a second one, “Fieldbus—Problems and Dependability Study”, which will be available in 2005 (Paris, Hermès/Ciame, 2005, in French).

p: Vincent Benard received his PhD in Automation Engineering from the University of Valenciennes (France) in December of 2004. He is currently a researcher in the LAMIH research laboratory (Laboratory of Industrial and Human Automation, Mechanics, and Computer Science), which is associated with the CNRS (National Center for Scientific Research). His research interests include the dependability evaluation of complex systems, particularly during the design phase.

Dominique Renaux obtained her doctorate from the University of Lille (France), and is an Associate Professor at the IUT in Valenciennes (University Institute of Technology). Her primary teaching responsibilities include courses on control systems, with a particular focus on the design, production, installation, and maintenance of automated systems (micro engineering, programmable logic controllers, slave control, and robotics). She is also a member of the LAMIH research laboratory (Laboratory of Industrial and Human Automation, Mechanics, and Computer Science), which is associated with the CNRS (National Center for Scientific Research). Her research focuses on dependability evaluation for complex systems, with an additional concentration in guided systems.

details.abstract: Dependability evaluation is a fundamental step in distributed control system design. However, the current dependability evaluation methods are not appropriate due to the level of complexity of such systems. Given the ineffectiveness of these methods, we propose the Safe-SADT formalism for dependability evaluation (SADT stands for Structured Analysis and Design Techniques). This formalism allows the explicit formalization of functional interaction, the identification of the characteristic values affecting complex system dependability, the quantification of RAMS parameters (Reliability, Availability, Maintainability, and Safety) for the system's operational architecture, and the validation of the operational architecture in terms of the dependability objectives and constraints required by the functional specifications. The results presented in this paper are limited to RAMS quantification

context.text:
The complexity of a distributed control system can be characterized from the different points of view that define it [23]:

•The functional point of view describes «what the system does»; the more numerous the system's functions, the more functionally complex the distributed control system will be.

•
The behavioral point of view indicates «what the system will become», providing information about the results of an overall system that is an aggregate of many entities (aggregate complexity), the various states of each entity (state complexity), and the stochastic transitions between those states (stochastic complexity).

•
The structural point of view highlights «who does what and with whom», with regard to a complicated composite structure (components, software, subsystems, systems, operators, teams, departments, factories, and environments) in which there are numerous horizontal and vertical interactions.

•
The technological point of view explains «what the system is made of», which, in most cases, means components that were not developed specifically for distributed control systems; called «on-shelf components» by some authors [24], such components often have poor or nonexistent documentation, as well as unknown or badly controlled failure modes.
